sen.e: Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume was a daughter of the Emperor Yuryaku and the Empress of Emperor Ninken.

sen.j: 母の名は『日本書紀』に春日臣深目の娘・童女君とある。
sen.e: As written in the "Nihonshoki," the mother of 'Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume' was "Ominagi" (童女君), a daughter of 'Kasuga no Omi Fukame' (春日臣深目).

sen.cmt: シングルクオート、ダブルクオートを削除しました。
sen.e: As written in the "Nihonshoki," the mother of Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume was Ominagi, a daughter of Kasuga no Omi Fukame.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では仁賢天皇との間に高橋大娘皇女、朝嬬皇女、手白香皇女（継体天皇の皇后・欽明天皇の母）、樟氷皇女、橘皇女（橘仲皇女、宣化天皇の皇后）、武烈天皇、真稚皇女を生んだとされる。
sen.e: According to the "Nihonshoki," as wife of the Emperor Yuryaku, "Ominagi" gave birth to the following children: Princess Takahashi no Oitsura no Hime [(高橋大娘皇女) Takahashi no Oitsura no Hime Miko)], Princess Asazuma no Hime [(朝嬬皇女) Asazuma no Hime Miko], Princess Tashiraka no Hime [(手白香皇女) Tashiraka no Hime Miko; the Empress of the Emperor Keita and the mother of the Emperor Kinmei], Princess Kusuhi no Hime [(樟氷皇女) Kusu no Hime Miko], Princess Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime [(橘皇女) Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime Miko; also known as "Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime Miko (橘仲皇女)"; the Empress of the Emperor Senka], the Emperor Buretsu, and Princess Mawaka no Hime [(真稚皇女) Mawaka no Hime miko].

According to the "Nihonshoki," as wife of the Emperor Ninken, Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume gave birth to the following children: Princess Takahashi no Oitsura no Hime, Princess Asazuma no Hime, Princess Tashiraka no Hime (Tashiraka no Hime Miko; the Empress of the Emperor Keitai and the mother of the Emperor Kinmei), Princess Kusuhi no Hime, Princess Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime (also known as "Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime Miko"; the Empress of the Emperor Senka), the Emperor Buretsu, and Princess Mawaka no Hime.
sen.cmt: “Ominagi”→Princess Kasuga no Oiratsumeに、Yuryaku→ Ninkenの変更およびKeita→Keitaiの訂正をしました。
sen.e: According to the "Nihonshoki," as wife of the Emperor Ninken, Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume gave birth to the following children: Princess Takahashi no Oitsura no Hime, Princess Asazuma no Hime, Princess Tashiraka no Hime (Tashiraka no Hime Miko; the Empress of the Emperor Keitai and the mother of the Emperor Kinmei), Princess Kusuhi no Hime, Princess Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime (also known as "Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime Miko"; the Empress of the Emperor Senka), the Emperor Buretsu, and Princess Mawaka no Hime.

sen.j: 『古事記』では高木郎女、財郎女、久須毘郎女、手白髪郎女、小長谷若雀命、真若王とある。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," children of Ominagi were written as follows: Takagi no Iratsume (高木郎女), Takara no Iratsume (財郎女), Kusubi no Iratsume (久須毘郎女), Tachiraka no Iratsume (手白髪郎女), Ohatsuse no Wakasazaki no Mikoto (小長谷若雀命), and Mawaka no Miko (真若王).

sen.cmt: “Ominagi”→Princess Kasuga no Oiratsumeに変更しました。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," children of Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume were as follows: Takagi no Iratsume, Takara no Iratsume, Kusubi no Iratsume, Tachiraka no Iratsume, Ohatsuse no Wakasazaki no Mikoto, and Mawaka no Miko.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、雄略天皇は采女の童女君がたった一夜で身ごもったために、生まれた春日大娘皇女が自分の娘であるかどうかを疑い、養育されなかった。
sen.e: According to the "Nihonshoki," because Ominagi as a uneme (a court lady), had became pregnant with the Emperor Yuryaku after spending only one night; then the Emperor Yuryaku had doubts as to whether this daughter (Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume) was truly his child or not. So, he did not raise her as her own.

sen.j: あるとき物部目大連 (古代日本)が庭を歩く女の子の姿を見て、天皇の姿によく似ていると述べた。
sen.e: One day, Mononobe no Me Omuraji saw the little girl (Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume) as she walked by in a garden inside the palace; later he told the Emperor Yuryaku, that the girl bore a strong family resemblance to him.

sen.j: 天皇はそれで、彼女の母が一夜で身ごもったのは異常であるため、自分の娘であるか疑っていると答えた。
sen.e: The Emperor Yuryaku answered, "Her mother had become pregnant following a one night stay with me, and that is unusual." Because of this, he had doubts about the daughter being his child.
The Emperor Yuryaku replied that he had doubts whether the daughter was his own child because he thought it was unlikely that her mother had become pregnant from one night stand.

sen.j: 物部目大連は天皇に一夜のうちに何度童女君を召したかを尋ねた。
sen.e: Mononobe no Me Omuraji asked to the Emperor Yuryaku, "How many times did you engage with Ominagi during the night?"

sen.j: 天皇は7度召したと答えた。
sen.e: The Emperor Yuryaku answered, "Seven Times."

sen.j: 物部目大連は天皇を諌めて、身ごもりやすい人は褌が体に触れただけで身ごもりますと述べた。
sen.e: Mononobe no Me Omuraji advised the Emperor Yuryaku that there were some women who would become pregnant more easily; then those women could become pregnant through contact with a fundoshi (a traditional under wear for male).

sen.j: そこで天皇は女の子を皇女とし、母の童女君を妃とした。
sen.e: Thus, the Emperor Yuryaku recognized the little girl (Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume) as an Imperial princess, and the mother was elevated to his princess (consort).

sen.j: この話は『古事記』には見られず、雄略天皇の系譜部分にも母・娘ともに名を欠いている。
sen.e: However, this story was not written in the "Kojiki," and the family genealogy of the Emperor Yuryaku missed the names of the mother and the daughter.

sen.j: なお、『古事記』において皇族出身の皇后の出自が、父である天皇の系譜で明らかでないのは、春日大娘皇女の他は、宣化天皇の皇后・橘仲皇女のみである。
sen.e: Additionally, in the "Kojiki," there were only two Empresses who were members of the Imperial family, which did not clear the paternal family lineage of their Emperors father's side: Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume and the Empress of Emperor Senka, Princess Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime.

Additionally, in the "Kojiki," there were only two Empresses, the Empress of Emperor Senka and Princess Tachibana no Nakatsu Hime, other than Prince Kasuga no Oiratsume, who were members of the Imperial family and do not appear in the paternal family lineage of their Emperors father's side.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味はこのようなことではないかと思って書きました。

sen.j: しかしながら娘の手白香皇女は、継体天皇の皇后となり、欽明天皇を産んでいる事から、春日大娘皇女は父・雄略天皇の血筋を唯一現在まで伝える存在となった。
sen.e: However, Princess Tashiraka no Hime, a daughter of Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume, became the Empress of the Keitai and gave birth to the Emperor Kinmei.

sen.j: この事から、春日大娘皇女は父・雄略天皇の血筋を唯一現在まで伝える存在となった
sen.e: Ironically, Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume was the only child who was to pass on the blood line of the father, the Emperor Yuryaku, to the future generations (to the modern times in Japan).
